code:
var mission = "

But for the climate crisis, I would be satisfied on a purely intellectual level as a theoretical particle physicist. However, the existential dread weighs heavily on me and I can't imagine not being a part of the solution. I therefore postponed any plans for a Ph. D. and pursued a career where I would use my technical skills to advance technological fixes to climate change. I got my start doing analytics at New Sun Road, a startup involved with solar microgrids in remote villages all over the world.

My time at New Sun Road was cut short by an early pandemic hiring freeze, and I found myself in a job market where all manner of climate tech startups were tightening their belts while more experienced candidates were looking to fill the available roles. A furious job hunt ultimately led me to ARISE High School in Oakland, where I spent two years as the physics, engineering, and computer science teacher. I learned a lot about myself and about the education system, enjoyed aspects of the job immensely, and cherished the relationships I built with students and fellow staff. But pandemic-era teaching was the hardest period in my life, and meanwhile my anxiety over the climate crisis continued to grow. I left ARISE in June 2022 and have been seeking a role in climate tech ever since.

During my last Spring at ARISE, I found a wonderful community of similarly concerned and climate-conscious citizens of Earth through the Climatebase Fellowship, a program to accelerate people's journeys into and through their climate careers. The learning and the connections have been immensely helpful in my climate career transition, but the enduring value I got from the fellowship was that for the first time ever, I didn't feel totally isolated in my feelings of existential dread. I'm not the only one fighting it constantly, as the Fellowship community continues to remind me every day.

"; export default mission;

sourcesContent:
const mission = `

But for the climate crisis, I would be satisfied on a purely intellectual level as a theoretical particle physicist. However, the existential dread weighs heavily on me and I can't imagine not being a part of the solution. I therefore postponed any plans for a Ph. D. and pursued a career where I would use my technical skills to advance technological fixes to climate change. I got my start doing analytics at New Sun Road, a startup involved with solar microgrids in remote villages all over the world.

My time at New Sun Road was cut short by an early pandemic hiring freeze, and I found myself in a job market where all manner of climate tech startups were tightening their belts while more experienced candidates were looking to fill the available roles. A furious job hunt ultimately led me to ARISE High School in Oakland, where I spent two years as the physics, engineering, and computer science teacher. I learned a lot about myself and about the education system, enjoyed aspects of the job immensely, and cherished the relationships I built with students and fellow staff. But pandemic-era teaching was the hardest period in my life, and meanwhile my anxiety over the climate crisis continued to grow. I left ARISE in June 2022 and have been seeking a role in climate tech ever since.

During my last Spring at ARISE, I found a wonderful community of similarly concerned and climate-conscious citizens of Earth through the Climatebase Fellowship, a program to accelerate people's journeys into and through their climate careers. The learning and the connections have been immensely helpful in my climate career transition, but the enduring value I got from the fellowship was that for the first time ever, I didn't feel totally isolated in my feelings of existential dread. I'm not the only one fighting it constantly, as the Fellowship community continues to remind me every day.

`; export default mission;
